reviewText:
I know its a 5-10 minute game but it is free and really fun, won't hurt to play the game through at least once and even at that you unlock a hardmode after finishing it. A little game that put a smile on my face watching this little creature trying to get back his lost documents to return them. Excited to play the game in this hopefully series !

Pros:

- Fun and cute game

- Free

- Even though its short and easy, they still give you a hardmode upon finishing the game (which is the same level but has a different layout to make it tougher)

- Will make you smile

-Will give you a Megaman feel (which is a good thing)

Cons:

- There really isn't any Cons to this game lol (you can use that the game being easy is one, but since you get a more tougher mode after first run I won't count it)

reviewText:
Pink Hour is a free platformer, done in a retro style that I just love. The sound and art are amazing, at least in my opinion and both really tug at nostalgia. The game is very short, and acts as a demo for the upcoming game Kero Blaster. There is also a squeal for Pink Hour in the works called Pink Heaven.  The gameplay itself reminds me of a cross between Mega Man and Bubble Bobble if that makes any sense to anyone.

To top off this review, I should mention that these games are from the same dev behind Cave Story.  If any of this sounds interesting, go try this game!

Update: Pink Heaven is now out, so here is a link to Pink Heaven, and a link to the upcoming Kero Blaster!

Link to Pink Heaven: http://store.steampowered.com/app/409690/

Link to Kero Blaster: http://store.steampowered.com/app/292500/

reviewText:
The Pink Hour is a short, free, promo game associated to Kero Blaster (Available on Steam).

It's a very simple platformer that should only take a few minutes to play. You play as an office worker who realizes her documents have been misplaced.... In a cave for some reason. A quick journey and a simple boss fight later, you either return to your office with the paper work, pleasing your boss (and getting to leave on time) OR if the document gets damaged, you have to work late.  :-(

It even has a cute epilogue, which can unlock a harder version of the cave with it's own ending.

The first time I played this game, my brain said This feels like Cave Story". I hadn't realized this was also made by Daisuke Amaya AKA Pixel
date: who created Cave Story.\n\nSo if you enjoy side scroll platformers
recommended: give this a try. If you like it

reviewText:
Pink Hour is simple and short, and considering that it's free, it's worth at least checking out. It's a typical 2D platformer. You can shoot and move and dodge obstacles and all that. The story is pretty silly, but cute. You play as Pink, an office worker, who must obtain a document for her boss in one piece. It's located underground, for some reason, and she can blast enemies, somehow. You gotta roll with it.

The difficulty is pretty simple, so it's not a particularly stressful endeavor, and a fair amount of people are going to beat this on their first go. The graphics are simple and pixelated, and not particularly bad, though not the neatest looking either. There's only one boss fight, but funnily enough, you can skip it if you jump far enough and at the right time to go over its head. There's two different endings you can get here; one for bringing the document back, and one for beating the game without it (if you get damaged, for example). The ending for beating it with the document gives you a short cutscene, leading to the store page for Kero Blaster, which is a nice way to promote your game (since this is an advertisement for the game, after all).

There's a hard mode you can unlock if you beat the game, which extends its replayability just a little bit. Because I'm not the best at video games, this took me a lot longer than it probably should have, but it's still pretty beatable in under an hour. What makes the mode so hard is that Pink (the character you control) tends to float when she jumps, which can make it easy to over or underaim when you jump. This isn't bad in the regular mode, but in hard mode, some platforms are only barely big enough to where you have to jump perfectly. I'm not particularly a fan of the perfect jump" difficulty in games
date: so a good portion of the hard mode wasn't too fun
recommended: and the second-to-last screen right after the boss fight took up maybe the most time on my hard mode attempts. However
voteText: you'll be able to get the rhythm down and blow through it pretty fast. There's an ending to unlock here if you beat it with the document
helpfulPercent: leading into either Kero Blaster or Pink Heaven.\n\nThe game is fun for the short amount of time it offers
votesHelpful: and while I'm not a fan of the jumping
votesTotal: the game isn't punishing and doesn't want to be arbitrarily hard. It's a nice relaxing time overall. Also
commentsCount: so there's no stress over cost per playtime. The one downside for some people may be that there are no achievements or trading cards
column16: but this isn't a loss in my book
column17: considering how straightforward the game is. Give it a go!"

This game also has a sequel: Pink Heaven.

reviewText: This is actually a demo for an upcoming game known as Kero Blaster. Pink Hour stars one of the side characters where you have to retrieve a document and give it to the president of some company you work for. It's a very simple and cute story and the pixel art I would describe as the same. The game itself is very simple as you can finish it under 10 minutes but when you unlock hard mode that is when the game becomes more interesting.\n\nI don't know how the full game is actually gonna be as I write this but I can tell you this demo definitely deserves a look if you're interested at all. It's a fun and free 2D platformer and you can't go wrong with that. And it's very cute so that's a plus for me. ^_^ I give it a 7/10

reviewText:
I played this short game for YouTube, not sure what to expect. To put it succinctly, it's a cocktease.

Granted, it's meant as a short interactive commercial for Kero Blaster, but it's still a damn nice retroesque platformer that's strangely reminiscent of Kirby in a way. The physics are great, controls and music are fantastic. I kinda wish this was a little bit longer, but it does its job (as capitalistic as it is).

It's definitely worth the five-to-ten minutes to play through.

reviewText:
I'm kind of torn on this one. I originally played the first release of this, which only came in the Hard Mode flavor; meaning that the game you start with now is actually severely toned down in difficulty from what it originally was. And toned down, it's a cute, serviceable little preview romp for Kero Blaster. I'd recommend it, sure.

The problem is that the formerly mandated Hard Mode (which you can still unlock by beating this on easy) is absolute screaming ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on toast. It's an agonizingly precision-based platformer over a series of instant death pits with Ninja Gaiden style bats flying in your face, and a player character that controls with ten times more inertia than is appropriate for this setup. I cannot make it past the first screen. This having been my first impression when it came out, it absolutely DESTROYED any and all interest I had in trying Kero Blaster, which I was previously reasonably hyped for. The lives system only makes it even worse.

So, go ahead and try it I guess, but don't expect anything good to come of Hard Mode.

There isn't too terribly much to talk about here with this one: if you've played Kero Blaster, this is more or less the length of  half a level in Kero Blaster. It's also just as good as half a level in Kero Blaster, so there's no real disappointment there. This game does have multiple endings which aren't too much of a bother to unlock, considering that a playthrough of this will last about 10 minutes. There aren't any upgrades, but there is a hard mode which changes the level quite a bit. My only complaint about Hard Mode is that the first screen is easily the hardest in the game, and the ones that follow are a lot more lenient. Still though, I managed to complete the game about five times over the course of the 30 minutes or so that I played. Nothing terribly amazing, but it's a good bit of fun for free. Check it out if you're a fan of Kero Blaster or are just looking to see what Kero Blaster is all about.

reviewText: A cute little shooter/platformer that you can beat in a single sitting. For a game with one level, it has some replay value. Took me an hour to get all four endings and had fun getting em' all. It's a nice little intro and ad for Studio Pixel's Kero Blaster which is coming out on Steam a few days from now. It would be fun if Studio Pixel continued making more little free-bees like this. The little pink secretary you play as is endearing and I'd definitely like to see more tiny games starring her.

There isn't too terribly much to talk about here with this one: if you've played Kero Blaster, this is more or less the length of  half a level in Kero Blaster. It's also just as good as half a level in Kero Blaster, so there's no real disappointment there. This game does have multiple endings which aren't too much of a bother to unlock, considering that a playthrough of this will last about 10 minutes. There aren't any upgrades, but there is a hard mode which changes the level quite a bit. My only complaint about Hard Mode is that the first screen is easily the hardest in the game, and the ones that follow are a lot more lenient. Still though, I managed to complete the game about five times over the course of the 30 minutes or so that I played. Nothing terribly amazing, but it's a good bit of fun for free. Check it out if you're a fan of Kero Blaster or are just looking to see what Kero Blaster is all about.

Pink Hour is pure Studio Pixel platformer bliss, Simple controls, beautiful graphics, cute story and a Hard Mode, for a little challenge. The sad part? It has 4 different ways to end, and it took me only half an hour to get them all, but how can I possibly complain, when it's a free game. Take a break and play it!

It's basically a playable ad for Kero Blaster. Compared to other experiments in interactive advertising like Pepsiman or Cool Spot this is high brow quality. Probably only relevant for those interested in Kero Blaster though.

Cute game.
A cute short platformer! The music and characters are sweet, a good free game to play for a quick break.

Pros:
- Free
- Cute pixle art style
- Multiple Endings and Hardmode adds a lot of replay

Cons:
- No power ups
- Health drops are too rare and placed in weird places
- Controls can be slippery

Overall:
Very enjoyable platformer/shooter, think Kirby meets Contra with a dash of Cave Story. Few problems but overall really well made and fun.

Meant as a demo/teaser for Kero Blaster, this game lasts for about 5min if you do just one run.\nCute graphics, cachty soundtrack and it's nice to replay it now and then, but the best part is that it features two difficulties with two endings each, and Hard Mode is actually rather challenging for such a short, cute game that was just made to be a teaser.\nIt's also free and extremely light and easy to run, so you literally have no reason not to download and play it immediatly.
It's...OK. Fun but short, so so very short. Download was longer than the game. But get it if you wana burn 10 minuets. (or 10,000 hours for hardmode).

A cute little platformer, it's really simple: you can move around, jump (and slow down your fall) and shoot at things and enemies. It's an incredibly short game with a simple but effective level deisgn and awesome retro graphics and sountrack, since it's incredibly short and free I can't think of a reason for not having it in your library...
